ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:0.2_0: The monks’ rules and their analysis
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:0.3_0: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.2_0: At that time it was winter, and the monks put furniture outside in order to warm themselves in the sun. But when the time for departure was announced, they departed without putting it away, having it put away, or taking leave.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.3_0: And the furniture was rained on.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.4_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.5_0: “How can those monks put furniture outside and then depart without putting it away, having it put away, or taking leave? The furniture was rained on.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.6_0: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.7_0: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.8_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.9.1_0: ‘If a monk takes a bed, a bench, a mattress, or a stool belonging to the Sangha and puts it outside or has it put outside, and he then departs without putting it away, having it put away, or taking leave, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.1.10_0: The Buddha has laid down a training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.2.1_0: Soon afterwards monks who had stayed outside brought the furniture back even though it was not the rainy season.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.2.2_0: The Buddha saw the dwellings in the morning
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.2.3_0: and after giving a teaching, he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:1.2.4_0: “Monks, during the eight months outside of the rainy season, I allow you to store furniture under a roof-cover or at the foot of a tree or wherever crows or ravens donʼt leave droppings.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.2_0: and you have the same kind of perception ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.4_0: ... The monks who have been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.6_0: it has been given to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.8_0: there are four kinds of beds:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.9_0: one with legs and frame, called _masāraka_; one with legs and frame, called _bundikābaddha_; one with crooked legs; one with detachable legs.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.11_0: there are four kinds of benches: legs, frame with legs and frame, called _masāraka_; one with detachable legs.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.13_0: there are five kinds of mattresses: a mattress stuffed with wool, a mattress stuffed with cloth, a mattress stuffed with bark, a mattress stuffed with grass, a mattress stuffed with leaves.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.15_0: one made of bark, one made of khus grass, one made of reed; it is upholstered and then bound together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.20_0: If he gets one who is not fully ordained to put it outside, it is the responsibility of the monk.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.21_0: If he gets one who is fully ordained to put it outside, it is the responsibility of the one who puts it outside.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.23_0: she does not herself end up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.27_0: if he does not take leave of a monk, a novice monk, or a monastery worker, then when he goes beyond the distance of a stone-throw of an average man, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.1_0: If it belongs to the Sangha, and he perceives it as such, and he puts it outside or has it put outside, and he then departs without putting it away or having it put away or taking leave, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.2_0: If it belongs to the Sangha, but he is unsure of it, and he hides his bowl or robe or sitting mat belonging to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.3_0: If it belongs to the Sangha, but he perceives it as belonging to an individual, and he puts it outside or has it put outside, and he then departs without putting it away or having it put away or taking leave, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.4_0: If he puts out a stone, a creeper, or has it put out, in a wooden shell, or by putting it away, having it put away, or taking leave, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.5_0: If it belongs to the Sangha, but he perceives it as belonging to an individual, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.6_0: If it has been an individual, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.7_0: If it is an individual, but he perceives it as belonging to another person, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.8_0: If it belongs to himself, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.3.3_0: if he departs after giving it to the place;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.3.4_0: if she goes, but not because of that;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.3.5_0: if he departs while he is sunning it;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.3.7_0: They burn in times of trouble,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.3.10_0: The fourth rule, the training rule on furniture, is finished.
